text:
This is the AI
Awakening, ECON295 CS2-- what is it-- 323.

So I hope you're
in the right room. I hope I'm in the right room. My name is Erik Brynjolfsson. I'm the professor
for this class.

And most importantly,
I really see this class as an exercise in cocreation. So I'm looking forward to
learning from all of you.

You're going to hear from
a lot of amazing speakers. And I know a little
bit about AI, but I think most
of the knowledge

is ultimately going
to come from you all, from the readings you
do, from the work you do, and the exercises.

So I really hope
you'll take the time to do the readings every
week, come to class prepared, ask smart questions
of the speakers,

work on the assignments
and the final projects. And I think you'll have
a great experience.

So let me actually start off
with a question for all of you, which is, do you have the
impression that AI progress,

tech progress is going a
little faster these days? And is it having a bigger impact
on the economy and society?

I see-- let's just raise hands. How many people get
that impression? All right. Most of you.

So if so if you
raised your hand, why do you think that's true? What do you think is going on?

Why is it possibly picking up? And actually so one
thing we'll do in class is everyone say their
name when they speak.

And we'll eventually
get to know most of you. Also, we do have
class participation, so that helps as well.
So what's your name?  Yes, [INAUDIBLE].

So I guess just the buzz
around large language models. We didn't have large language
models two years ago.

We do now. And-- It seems there's
a buzz around it. So there's a lot
of hype out there.

There's evidence. There's been some
surveys that Pew has done that found that I
think 18% of people in the US

workforce have used ChatGPT
at work at least once. Only 18%?

OK. I guess I'm in a little
bit of a bubble here. Yeah. It's still pretty high. Tyler, Texas lives
outside our bubble.

But then there's all the
media hype and all that. But the way you
said it, it sounds like it's a phenomena of
people learning about it

and there's a buzz about it. Is there more to it than that? Well, I guess, euphoria
with NVIDIA stock.

There's actual obviously a
lot of large tech companies
that are actually pursuing it. There seems to be-- there's a barrier to entry. So we all see that.
Definitely, I agree. That's a big part of it. But why?
Yeah. Sorry. State your name. Sorry. I don't know your-- this is going to be really easy.

I would posit the two
big reasons are access to compute and access to
infrastructure, especially

before the ChatGPT
era, people were [? treating ?] language models. The big problem with this
is like people weren't sure

exactly how good
the amount of data and the amount of compute
we're throwing at these models

would result-- what the result of these
investments would be. So I believe it's the fact
that compute is getting better,

but there's also this
self-fulfilling cycle where people are starting to
realize that using more compute

and getting these models to
learn from all these large scale data sets actually
allow us to create

useful real-world systems. And because of that,
there's more investment in infrastructure.

OK. And so that additional compute
and more spending on it,

better processors allowing them
to train bigger models and-- are they any better?

I mean, of course,
they're definitely better than eight years ago. Eight years ago?

Yeah. That sounds kind of
faint praise to me. Yeah. I mean-- How about right behind you
there, what do you think?
[INAUDIBLE] A lot harder.

OK. I'm going to update
my algorithm. But I guess perhaps going back
to your original question which

was, do you feel like
AI is impacting us in the workforce more
or technology in general

than it used to? Well, it's two questions. There's is the
technology changing. We're perceiving more of it.

There's [? something. ?]
And then is it having a bigger impact? But it sounds like maybe you're
going for the second one?

The second question then. I can't say exactly if
it has a bigger impact,

but I think there
is a perception that it has greater impact. And I think perhaps in
the past, technology

has largely been focused
on specific verticals or specific industries. But it feels like AI has
the capacity of impacting

broadly all industries. And in that sense, the
perception of its impact

feels a lot closer to a
larger majority of people. Yeah. Yeah. And at least 18% of
people are beginning

to play around with it a bit. Yeah. How about here? I would say that more
recently, us as consumers

have been feeling the
impact of a lot more. I've raised the
example of ChatGPT because it's one of the
first examples of AI kind

of having this interface
that you and I can just access for free. Before this, it was
locked behind [INAUDIBLE]

who knows where. Yeah. Yeah. I'm still curious. I know there's some computer
science AI students in here.

Getting to the core technology,
we've got more compute. And it's better than
it was eight years ago.

I'd like to hear
a little bit more about what's changing
in the technology. You have something
to say about that?

I was going to talk about
the previous comment. I was just going to say
I think the perception-- Sorry, what's your name?

I was going to
say, the perception that AI is changing
the workforce and revolutionizing the
economy is far greater

than the reality estimates. There are only actually
about $3 billion in generative AI software
revenues in 2023.

And that's not including
if you take out the benefit that Google and
Meta got from using

AI to improve their algorithms. If you ask most people who
work in the real world,

people's jobs aren't really
fundamentally changing. So I think that there's
tremendous potential

in the future. But for today, I think
it hasn't really changed. Hasn't really moved the
productivity numbers or whatever

or the way businesses
are working. How about my question about
the technology, though?

Who's got a little
bit of technology? Over here. Yeah. I guess there's a slight irony
in the way in the adoption

of LLM-based or
transformer-based large language models and the fact that the
transformer is an eight-year-old

architecture. But I think AI as a
field has been amenable

to really fast iterations, more
so than almost any other field.

And the recent, I guess, influx
of funding into the space

has unlocked a much
broader range of research of the technology, not only
from the capabilities side

but also on the interpretability
side and just more,

I guess, interdisciplinary
approaches to this one particular field.

Yeah. Great. I think that makes a
lot of sense as well. Any other comments on that yet?

Yeah. So there's this very interesting
perspective in research. And a lot of people in ML
research have heard of it.

It's called like Richard
Sutton's The Bitter Lesson. And basically, the
idea behind this is that a lot of the
advances we see today in AI

are due to the fact
that we're just building models that
can better leverage data and better learn from the
big data and better scale

with the current
compute we have. And maybe a lot of
the more tangential like algorithmic
advances are actually

as useful as people
[? say. ?] Yeah. So in terms of technology, we
have seen advances in modeling,

like, mixture of experts,
diffusion models, to cite a few. So there are methods which are
kind of giving us a greater

ability to learn from these
large data sets and leverage all this compute,
part of the reason why

we are seeing these advances. How many people here
have read The Bitter Lesson, Richard Sutton's thing.

Yeah. OK. I'm going to add it too. There's only a few pages long. And I think it should be called
the wonderful lesson actually,

not the bitter lesson. But his point is that-- it may
be bitter for AI researchers,

sorry. But his point is that AI
researchers were coming up with all these new techniques
and algorithms and ways

of trying to capture
knowledge and teach machines how to do tasks. And it kind of worked.

You could teach it,
here's how to play checkers or chess or
more advanced things,

how to understand language. This is a verb. This is a noun. But the bitter lesson is that
each time, progress ultimately

came not so much just from that,
but from more data and more

compute. And so take the
example of language. The reason that it's
gotten so good at language

is that we've been able to throw
a lot more compute, a lot more power with a lot more words.

And just the machines
have learned-- we're going to show
you a little while-- I'll explain a little bit more
about what machine learning

and how that's different. And the machines have
learned how to understand it. And you don't really need
all that syntax and grammar

and other stuff that
they were trying to teach the machines in
order to get some pretty decent language understanding.

And I use the word
understanding advisedly. Chris Manning, one of the
giants of the field of NLP

whose office is here,
he said it was OK for me to call it understanding,
so I'm going

to go ahead and go with that. So that's a bitter
lesson, maybe in a way that AI researchers were
just being overwhelmed

by more compute, more data. Maybe it's a good lesson
because that gives us a path.

And one of the things that a
lot of these companies are doing is investing in that now
they understand this lesson.

And so that is a path
towards better progress. Of course, it's a little bit
of an oversimplification. Some of each is important.

And if I were really to
say three things that have driven this revolution,
one is more compute,

one is a lot more data. It used to be like when you
guys were little children,

most of the world did not have
a lot of digital data, photos,

messages were generally
sent in analog form. Now they're pretty
much all digitized.

And there's vastly more digital
data, orders of magnitude, more digital data than it was
in the '70s or '80s or even

the '90s. And that's the lifeblood. So the compute, the data. And the third thing I
want to keep on the list

is better algorithms,
more parameters, more advances in things
like the transformer,

which is a big invention. Some people think it may
be one of the biggest inventions in history that
allows us to manage this

more effectively. And it took a little while to
realize how powerful it was. The paper didn't get
that much attention

when it was first published
by the team at Google. But very quickly, people started
realizing how powerful it was.
So is there a question? Someone had a hand. OK. Yes. Sorry, what's your name? Mine was going to-- Wait, wait.

Sorry. Sorry. Hi. This was going towards a
different part of the question

and I guess less technical. But it was going back towards
specifically the word impression

and the type of impression. And I think so much of
the impression of AI is that the commercialization
of these language models,

for example, ChatGPT, whether
you look at what is Gemini now, has allowed so many other
startups and companies to build

upon the existing infrastructure
and technology, which is making it accessible and so
interdisciplinary,

which is making the buzz
experience so much more helpful

across. Right. I think so. So we're building
on all of that. So there are a number of
things that are happening here,

the technology, other
people building on it. And I do think that the
underlying technological

innovations are really
important, partly because of Richard
Sutton's Bitter Lesson, partly because of genuine
improvements in algorithms

and approaches. And we're just beginning
to see some impact in terms of people using it.

I've gone to Congress
a bunch of times to talk to people about AI. And I can tell you, most
of the time when I said,

I'm an economist, I'm here
to talk about technology, their eyes would
start glazing over. And they would kind of
politely listen and try

and change the subject. But now they're all like
hanging on every word. I show up and they've read
all my papers in advance

in the White House and
Congress because they really see that this is beginning
to have a big effect. The dollars may not
be that big right

now in terms of the
productivity effect, but everyone's betting
that they will be. And I'll show you
some reasons why they think they're betting that
that's a plausible bet to make.

In fact, I would
go so far as to say that the impact,
the economic changes

are lagging way behind the
potential of the technology. So one way to think about that
is if somehow something terrible

happened and all tech
progress just froze, all the technologists
went on strike or there was a big
earthquake or something

that stopped tech progress
in AI for the next 5, 10, 20

years, maybe more,
we would continue to have progress in
business innovation and economic productivity
growth as people figured out

ways of implementing the stuff
that's already been invented and that's available today and
that needs to be implemented.

Yes. Your name? I had, I guess, half a question,
half comment about like--

your original question
was like the risk or if the technology is
outpacing the economy and society.

And you also talked about
the importance of new data for training these
models, but is a huge issue with the models
that currently exist that we're

kind of running out
of data and it's being trained on
AI-generated data, which is augmenting hallucinations.

That would be a
really bitter lesson. Yeah. If data is what drives it,
and then we run out of data.

I know that some of my
speakers are going to dive into that with more expertise. So it's a really
important question

because the reason
models have been trained on almost all the
data on the internet, they've just scraped it all.

They've read or been trained
on most of the words in books. So where are you going to
get the additional data?

If you're going to keep having
more data, more compute, well, you're
running into limits. And there's a genuinely
open question as to

whether or not you can
use synthetic data, which seems a little crazy.

You have a machine,
generate a sentence, and then you train
it on that sentence. How could that possibly work?

But we'll hear from some
speakers who say, yeah, maybe that is working in some context. And you can see a few places
where it clearly does work.

How many of you have
heard of AlphaZero? So how was that trained?
so. Who else? Yeah, so over here.

It was trained
through self-play. Well, for chess, it
played against itself. Yeah.
Not just chess. Also Go. Yeah. So that was synthetic data. It's the alpha--

AlphaGo was trained
on human-played games. It had all those
games it recorded,

what each person moved. And it said, when in
this board position, this is the move that was made.

And it, from that,
learned new rules. AlphaZero was trained on, as its
name implies, zero human data.

But it knew the rules. So it generated its own games
and saw what would happen.

And it did that billions
or trillions of times. And so when you have a
well-defined set of rules,

you can generate lots of
data and learn from that. And some people try to do
that with physics engines,

like maybe for robotics or
for driving simulations.

Maybe you can
generate some data, or maybe you have a video of a
professor lecturing to a class

and then they start getting a
sense not from the text or voice

data, but maybe from the
way people are interacting that, he dropped his pen. So that says something.

Maybe you can infer
something about gravity from that or other things. And those are also possibilities
of generating data that

wasn't recorded previously. But it's an open
question and how much you can do from synthetic
data or other kinds.

And we'll see. My suspicion is that there
are certain problems they'll be very amenable to
it, playing games

if you have well-defined rules. Other ones where it
may be very difficult. And then they will
be working on that.

But that's an open-- And one of the subtexts
of your question is that a lot of--
if you go to the web

today, a lot of the content
is generated by LLMs. Like I'm on Twitter, which
I probably shouldn't be,

but I just logged in and I
saw a whole bunch of bots are following me and
they're responding to me.

I can tell that they're bots
because they're not that good. But somebody who
scrapes Twitter is now going to get a bunch
of LLM-generated data

and use that to
train the next one. And I don't know, that
could get dysfunctional. Did you want to say something.

I wanted to say, I think a risk,
social economic risk that I think we're all very
aware of is like we all

came into this class
with expectations of policy applications
or government applications or
different companies that we could possibly
launch with this technology.

But the bottom line
is we don't even know how it's going
to malfunction, and that's really scary. Right. There's some known unknowns
that we know there's

some risks in all those areas. And there's some
unknown unknowns that we haven't even imagined
yet, something unexpected.

And that's something
we want to think about. And after class, I encourage
you to stick around. It's optional.

But from 6:00 to 7:00, we're
going to sit in a circle upstairs and I want to hear
about everybody's interest

and what they're hoping
to get out of the class. What are their concerns about
AI and their hopes for AI?

We don't have time to do
that right now during class. But those who want to, we
can do that afterwards. That will help for
team formation as well.

So there's clearly a
lot of hype out there, a lot of unfounded
claims, especially

I think it gets worse
the further away you get from Stanford
that there's just

people who aren't that
familiar with the stuff and are just making stuff up. But it happens
around here as well.

But there's also unquestionably
something fundamental, something real going
on with the technology.

One of the reasons that I
came over from MIT to Stanford about four years ago
is I wanted to be a little closer to where
a lot of the people who

were inventing it. I think we're all
very lucky to be here at this place at this time.

And so I very frequently
ask AI researchers, like it's one of
the first questions. I ask if I talk to a new
one, where are you surprised?

Is this unexpected? And almost invariably, they
say yes, I was surprised.

They did not expect
this improvement. And I'll show you a chart later
that summarizes that a bit.

But there has been a
genuine inflection, C change in the capabilities.

And that in turn is going
to trigger more and more economic changes over time.

But what I see happening is a
improving rate of technology,

perhaps even exponential
in some cases and not much change or
improvement in our business

institutions, our culture,
our economic understanding. And so there's a gap
that's growing there.

And in that gap is where most-- I think most or many of our
challenges and opportunities

in the coming decade lie. And part of my mission in life
and with the digital economy lab

and in this class is
to close that gap. I know some people try to close
the gap by stopping technology.

I'm more focused on speeding
up our understanding. And I'm hoping
that in this class, we can do a little bit of
that because ultimately,

the changes in society are
going to depend on us being able to have that
better understanding and understanding how
economics has to be updated,

how business processes and
institutions need to be updated. So like I said, I think
there's no more exciting time

to be alive than now and
no more exciting place to be than right here. Revealed preference I came here.

A real preference, you
guys all came here as well. So let me go through some
of the content I wanted

to cover for today's class. And then we're going
to go over the syllabus and the requirements and
answer what questions you

may have about all of that. So try a little game
next time you're

hanging out with your roommates
or meeting some new people or your in-laws or whatever. And what I propose you
do is you ask them,

look at all of history. What were the most important
things that happened in history?

Big question. I was just over in England,
and over there, some people think it's kings and
queens and empires.

Some people think it's
plagues and conquests.

But when you really think
about it, most of those things weren't that important.

I mean, how can I say that? Well, I'm an economist. And one way to measure it
is the living standards

of the average person. Most people on Earth, they
were living a little bit above subsistence level.

And then a century
later, kind of the same. Millennium later,
kind of the same.

The average life of
the average person, despite all these things
happening in the history books,

didn't really change a whole
lot, until around 1775, 1776.

What happened there? Well, American
Revolution, maybe.

I don't know. Adam Smith published
The Wealth of Nations. Some people would say
escaped the poverty trap.

Yeah, definitely. Definitely. Well, how did they escape it? This is still a highly debated
topic in economic growth.

But some people
like here and others say that there were certain
institutions, British Parliament

and so forth, a lot
of property rights exist that allowed all this
innovation invention in Britain and those innovations
built up elsewhere.

They spilled over. I have a much more
simple answer.

The steam engine,
new technology. I think all that stuff
probably was important and maybe it helped the
discovery of the steam engine.

You could say why? Why? Why? But James Watt in Scotland
made a big improvement

to the steam engine,
so it started becoming really practically useful. And they started adapting
it to a lot of things.

And because of some of
the institutional changes you mentioned, Jonathan, sort
of rippled and other inventions

came along. But the steam engine
essentially ignited the industrial revolution.

And it allowed us to instead of
having our own muscles or animal muscles, use machines
to move things around

and to do important
physical work. And ever since then,
living standards

have grown at a compounded
exponential rate of about a couple
percent per year. So we are, I don't know,
30 or 50 times richer

than our ancestors were
a couple of years ago. The steam engine
was the first GPT.

Anybody know what I'm
referring to when I say GPT? I'm probably going to get it
wrong, but, yeah, go ahead.

Yes. Yes, exactly. Good I'm glad that
economists still get to use the word GPT for
General Purpose Technology, not

Generative Pretrained
Transformer. So a general purpose technology,
steam engine was the first,

but it wasn't the last. There's others like
electricity, computers.

GPTs have these three
important characteristics according to Tim Bresnahan
and Manuel Trajtenberg. They're pervasive.

That is, they affect broad
sectors of the economy. They're able to be
improved over time.

And last but most
importantly, they able to spawn
complimentary innovations.

So they trigger changes in
transportation, in factory work, and other kinds of work.

So these GPTs include
artificial intelligence.

It is a GPT. It ticks all of
those boxes as well. Yeah, question.

One might assume that
the internet was a GPT, but I would argue like it
didn't create the same J-curve
of the productivity. J-curve. Wow. Yeah.

So to be fair, there's not like
a black and white line between this is a GPT and this isn't.

I think there's gradations. And the internet
did trigger a bunch of complementary innovations.

It did trigger widespread
productivity growth in the '90s and early 2000s.

And we're still
benefiting in some ways perhaps that aren't
measured, but probably not in the scale of electricity
or the steam engine.

So that's probably--
I mean, these are continuous
variables, not Booleans.

So AI is a GPT. In fact, I would argue
that to your point,

there are GPTs of
different magnitudes. And it might arguably
be the most general

of all general
purpose technologies because-- anyone know
who this guy is, Demis? Anyone ever been to Kings
Cross at his offices because he

has a little slogan
there for DeepMind. He's the founder of
DeepMind or cofounder.

"Our goal is to
solve intelligence, and then use that to solve
all the other problems in the world." So very modest.

I'm sure when you
guys start businesses, you'll also have modest
missions like that one.

But there's some truth to it. If you can solve intelligence,
whatever that means,

you're going to be able to
address a lot of other problems in the environment, in health
care, poverty, more consumer

goods. There's lots of things you
can do with more intelligence. So in that sense, it is a
very general, general purpose

technology. Some people call it
the ultimate invention because invents all the
other ones, potentially.

And that is what we're
working on right now. And there are metrics-- I'll show you some data--

that we're solving parts
of intelligence in a way that we never did before. In fact, here's
one set of metrics.

You guys all know
about ImageNet? Fei-Fei Li here in this
building put together

a data set of about
14 million images along with our collaborators.

And each of them were
painstakingly labeled. That's a starfish. That's an antelope,
or is it a gazelle? And you had to be careful
about labeling them all.

And then there were
contests starting back in 2010 for machines to
try to identify them.

And I used to say that
machines just aren't very good at image recognition.

In my book, Second
Machine Age, I gave recognizing a face as
something that people could do, but machines couldn't
really do very well.

Well, that was then. Now we know that they're very
good at image recognition and face recognition.

In fact, on many metrics,
they're better than humans. Humans are better in some,
machines are better in others.

And there's that steep
inflection point there around 2012. Anybody know what
happened in 2012?

Convolutional neural
networks and AlexNet came up. Yeah. And were applied to ImageNet.

And so Jeff Hinton and his
team introduced deep learning techniques, these
neural networks

with lots and lots of layers. In some of the future classes,
we'll read about them. And that turned out to be really
effective at doing these tasks.

And the next year, everybody
started introducing them. And we started having
progress in that.

And if you go to the
AI index, there's a new report coming
out in about 10 days--

I'm a co-author on that-- has hundreds of charts
like this showing

progress in lots of dimensions. Do I have it on my
next point here? Well, let me do this one. Here's one that summarizes
some of the things.

There are lots and lots of these
metrics that are improving. And it's a little-- This is not from DEI index,
but depending on the benchmark,

you can say humans
are able to do a certain level of performance. And last year in this
room in this class,

Jack Clark gave a
bunch of these charts and said one of
the problems they were having is that every
time someone made a benchmark,

someone else would
figure out a way to get a machine to beat that
benchmark relatively quickly. So they're trying to come up
with some more long-lasting

and robust benchmarks. Yeah. One quick question
on that figure. So I'm assuming the 0% points
are just when the benchmark

or data set came out. Yeah. Yeah. This is a-- yeah, exactly. That doesn't mean
zero performance.

I think actually if you
go back, this is probably a better representation.

But they're all normalized to
be between those two numbers. Yeah, kind of a scale.

So it's worth categorizing
a few different regimes. So when artificial
intelligence was first--

the field was first founded
back in 1956, a group of people got together at
Dartmouth and coined it

and started working
on it, it was mostly focused on symbolic methods. People were working
on neural networks,

but they were very, very
shallow because we don't have much computational power. It's like a single
layer neural network.

And when I started
working in AI, I taught my first class not
here, but at Harvard Extension

School right after I graduated
as an undergraduate in 1985, we were building expert
systems, rule-based systems.

And they were
painstakingly hand-coded. So you would talk to an expert,
ask them their if/then rules

for diagnosing a fever
or figuring out which wine to choose or whatever. You'd write them down.

And by chaining together a
bunch of these if/then rules, you could sometimes get
pretty good answers on things.

But per Richard
Sutton's Bitter Lesson, it didn't really
scale very well. And it was filled with errors.

And it didn't really take off. There was a bit of an
AI bubble in the '80s. People were very excited, but
it kind of fizzled and turned

into an AI winter. But that's where machine
learning came in. And as Rich Sutton was
saying, a new approach.

Some people call
it software 2.0. And the idea behind
machine learning is instead of we humans telling
the machine what to do--

and you guys have all
coded at some point. You know that if
you write code, you have to know exactly
what you want it to do.

If you write a word
wrong or a comma wrong, the machine isn't going
to do what you want.

But with machine
learning, you don't need to know exactly how
to solve the problem. Instead, what you do is you
have a lot of data on inputs,

a lot of data on
outputs, and the machine learns the relationships
between them,

the statistical
relationships between them. And you can get a lot of
effective predictions that way.

That if you ask them both
questions behind a curtain, you can't tell which
one is the human and which one is the machine.

And more broadly,
the idea that AI means replicating humans

I don't think it's a good

that he's developed antigravity?

He made it look like that. But it's really not

in being able to understand it? And so I think you

setting aside whether it's

To be more precise,
you can develop technologies that are
substitutes or technologies that

are complements. A substitute does
the same thing.

Two things are substitutes
if they can be, one can replace the other. And the more of
substitute A you have,

they drive down human labor. But you can also
have compliments. A complement is
something that makes

the other thing more valuable. My left shoe is a compliment
for my right shoe. Software is a
compliment for hardware.

A bottle cap is a
compliment for the bottle. Compliments make the other
object more valuable.

For some reason, most of
us, even me sometimes, think of technology
primarily as substitutes.

We think, how can
this technology be used to do what a human
is doing, like Alan Turing?

The reality is that
through most of history, most technologies
have been complements.

Most technologies
have not driven down the value of human labor. They've increased it.

A person with a computer is

So through most of history,
machines have mostly

been compliments, have
mostly amplified human labor. And looking forward, that's what
we'd like to see machines do,
